content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Ryan Henderson: I was born and raised in Philadelphia, in a tight-knit neighborhood on the East Side. My parents were both college-educated, which gave me a solid foundation growing up. My father worked as a teacher, and my mother was a nurse, though she took a break from her career to raise my sister and me. We were a traditional family, and I was raised in an Orthodox-Christian household, though I've become more secular as I've gotten older. I always felt a bit torn between the strict religious values I was brought up with and the more liberal views I started to develop in high school. I was pretty active in school, involved in debate club and student government, and I always had a passion for writing and politics. I went to college on a scholarship, got my Bachelor's in Political Science, and thought I was on a path to maybe working in public service. But after graduation, the economy took a hit, and I found myself laid off from a job I had at a local nonprofit. I've been trying to get back on my feet ever since, and it's been a tough few years, but I'm still hopeful.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Ryan Henderson: There was definitely a crossroads, and it came right after I graduated from college. I had been accepted into a master's program in Public Policy at a pretty reputable university, and I was also offered a job as a policy analyst at a local think tank. Both opportunities seemed like they would lead me toward the kind of work I wanted to do—making a difference in people's lives through policy. But I was also dating someone at the time, and we had talked about moving to a different city together. She was from Chicago, and she wanted to be closer to her family. I had always imagined staying in Philadelphia, but I felt like I needed to support her. So I turned down the master's program and the job offer, and we moved to Chicago. Looking back, I think that was the biggest decision I ever made. It changed the course of my life in ways I couldn't have predicted. I ended up working at a nonprofit there, but the economy tanked just a few years later, and I got laid off. I wasn't able to find work in the same field, and I ended up moving back to Philadelphia, where I've been trying to rebuild my career ever since. I often wonder if I would be in a better place now if I had stayed in Philadelphia and pursued that master's degree. But I also think that decision taught me a lot about compromise, about the importance of relationships, and about how life doesn't always go the way you plan.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Ryan Henderson: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt more like a leap of faith than a calculated decision. I knew the risks involved, but I also believed that being with the person I loved was more important than any career path at that moment. I didn't just 'fall into' the situation—I made the choice to prioritize our relationship, even if it meant stepping away from what I thought was my future. That said, I don't think I was entirely aware of how much the world would change in the years that followed. I was young, idealistic, and maybe a little too confident in my ability to navigate whatever came next. Looking back, I realize that decision was both a blessing and a challenge. It taught me the value of love and sacrifice, but it also forced me to confront the reality that life doesn't always reward compromise with the outcomes you expect.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Ryan Henderson: Absolutely. When I moved to Chicago, I was pretty naive about how the job market worked there, especially in the nonprofit sector. I remember reaching out to a few local organizations and even attending a few networking events, but I didn't have the same connections I had back in Philadelphia. If someone had taken the time to mentor me or connect me with people in the field, it might have made a big difference. I also think that if I had stayed in Philadelphia and pursued that master's degree, I might have had more stability during the economic downturn. But at the time, I didn't see it that way. I was focused on making the relationship work, and I didn't realize how much I was setting myself back professionally. Looking back, I wish I had been more proactive in seeking out support or guidance, but I also understand why I didn't. I was young, and I thought I could handle it on my own.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Ryan Henderson: I'm currently married to the same person I moved to Chicago with. We've been through a lot together, and while our relationship has had its ups and downs, we've managed to stay committed. We have a daughter, Emily, who's six years old. She's a bright kid, always asking questions and curious about the world. I think she's inherited some of my love for politics and debate, though she's more interested in animals and science right now. My wife, Sarah, works as a social worker, and while it's a demanding job, she's passionate about it. We live in a small apartment in South Philly now, and while it's not the most luxurious place, it feels like home. I try to be a good father and husband, but it's not always easy. Between the job search and trying to keep up with Emily's needs, there are days when I feel like I'm barely keeping my head above water. Still, I wouldn't trade this life for anything. I've learned a lot about resilience, about what really matters, and I hope I'm setting a good example for Emily as she grows up.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the chapters of my life that I haven't always had the chance to reflect on deeply. Talking about my childhood, my family, and the crossroads I faced after college brought back a lot of emotions—some I had long buried, others I still grapple with. It was strange to realize how much my choices, especially the one to move to Chicago, shaped the person I am today. I've always thought of that decision as a sacrifice for love, but hearing myself explain it again made me see how much it also cost me in terms of my career and stability. Still, I wouldn't undo it. Life has a way of teaching us through its challenges, and I've learned more about myself, my values, and what truly matters in the process. I'm not where I thought I'd be at this point in my life, but I'm still standing, and that's something to be grateful for.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Ryan Henderson: My immediate family includes my parents, my sister, and my brother-in-law. My parents are still in Philadelphia, and while we don't see each other as often as I'd like, we keep in touch through phone calls and occasional visits. My father is retired now, but he was a teacher for over thirty years, and he still has that quiet authority about him. My mother, on the other hand, is more of a nurturer—she's always been the one to keep our family together, even when things got tough. My sister, Claire, is a few years older than me, and she's a lawyer in New York. We have a good relationship, though we've had our share of sibling rivalry growing up. She's always been the more ambitious one, and I think she sometimes sees me as the 'safe' choice, the one who didn't take as many risks. But I don't mind that. I think we both have our own paths, and I respect what she's built for herself. My brother-in-law, Mark, is Sarah's brother, and he's been a good support to us since we got married. He's a firefighter in Chicago, and while our lives are different, he's always there for us when we need it. I think family is one of the few constants in my life, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Ryan Henderson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Jake, who I met in college. We were in the debate club together, and we bonded over our shared interest in politics and social issues. He ended up moving to DC after graduation and got involved in some advocacy work. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but I still respect his passion and dedication. Then there's Priya, who I met in Chicago through a community center. She was one of the first people to really welcome me into the city, and we became close friends. She's a graphic designer, and she's always been a source of creativity and inspiration for me. Even though we haven't seen each other in a while, I still think of her often. There's also a group of friends from my college days who I keep in touch with through social media and occasional meetups. They've all taken different paths, but I'm proud of where they are in life. I think friendship is one of the things I value most, even if I haven't always been the best at maintaining those connections. Life gets busy, and sometimes people fall out of touch, but I believe in the importance of those relationships, even when they're not always easy to sustain.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Ryan Henderson: I live in a neighborhood called South Philly now, and it's a place that feels like a mix of old and new. There's a lot of history here—some of the oldest buildings in the city, with brick streets and row houses that have seen generations of families come and go. But at the same time, there's a lot of energy, a lot of diversity, and a strong sense of community. I love the local markets, the little coffee shops, and the way the streets come alive in the evenings with music and conversation. It's not always easy—there are parts of the neighborhood that can be rough, and I've had to be careful with where I go at night. But for the most part, it's a place that feels alive, and I think that's what keeps me here. I've seen a lot of changes in the area over the years, and I know it's not the same as when I was growing up, but I like the idea that it's still evolving. It's a place where I can raise Emily, where she can learn about the world around her, and where I can try to build something better for us.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Ryan Henderson: I'd say I feel pretty safe here, but it's not without its challenges. South Philly has a strong sense of community, and there are plenty of people who look out for one another. I know the cops around here, and they're generally pretty responsive if something's wrong. Still, I'm careful about where I go and who I'm with, especially after dark. There are parts of the neighborhood that have seen better days, and I've had to be mindful of that. But overall, I think the people here are good, and I feel like I can walk my daughter to the park or take her to the library without too much worry. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I think that matters more than anything.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Ryan Henderson: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, the neighborhood has a real sense of community, and I've met some amazing people—neighbors who check in on each other, local shop owners who know your name, and kids like Emily who run around the block and make friends with everyone. It's a place where you can feel connected, even if life is tough. On the other hand, it's not always easy to find stable work, and the cost of living here has gone up a lot since I moved back. I've had to take on a few part-time jobs just to make ends meet, and that's not ideal when you're trying to build a career. But I think the biggest thing is that it's given me a chance to be present for Emily. I can take her to the park, read her a bedtime story, and be there for her when she needs me. That's something I wouldn't trade for anything. Even when things are hard, I feel like I'm giving her a life that's real, that's grounded, and that's full of possibilities.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my wife, Sarah, and our daughter, Emily, reminded me how much my life has changed since moving back to Philadelphia. I used to think about my career more than anything, but now I realize that being a father and husband is what truly matters. When I described South Philly, I felt a mix of pride and frustration—pride in the community spirit and the history, but frustration with the challenges of finding stable work and the rising cost of living. It was also interesting to reflect on how I feel about safety here. I know it's not perfect, but I've learned to trust the people around me, and that gives me a sense of security that I didn't always have before. Overall, these questions made me think about how far I've come and how much I've grown, even if I'm not exactly where I thought I'd be.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Ryan Henderson: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. Most mornings start with getting Emily up, getting her ready for school, and then trying to squeeze in a few minutes of coffee and reading before the day really kicks off. I work a few different part-time jobs—sometimes I do data entry for a small business, other times I help out at a community center with administrative tasks. It's not the most glamorous work, but it pays the bills and gives me some structure. After work, I try to be there for Emily as much as I can—helping with homework, taking her to soccer practice, or just hanging out in the park. On weekends, we usually have family dinners with my parents or my sister if she's in town. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's going for a run, reading a book, or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood come to life. It's not the life I imagined for myself when I was younger, but it's the life I have now, and I'm learning to find peace in that.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Ryan Henderson: I work a few different part-time jobs to make ends meet. Most weekdays, I start with a morning shift doing data entry for a small local business—usually from around 8 a.m. to 11 a.m. After that, I head over to a community center in the afternoon, where I help with administrative tasks like filing, organizing events, and assisting with outreach programs. It's not the kind of work I ever imagined myself doing, especially after college, but it keeps me busy and gives me a sense of purpose. I try to be there for Emily as much as I can, so I usually wrap up by around 3 or 4 p.m. so I can pick her up from school and help with her homework. On some days, I'll take on an extra shift in the evening, especially if the community center needs more help with a special event or if I need to cover some unexpected expenses. It's not ideal, but I've learned to be flexible. I know I'm not where I thought I'd be at this point in my life, but I'm trying to make the best of it, and I hope that one day I'll find something more fulfilling.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Ryan Henderson: Outside of work and family, I've also taken on some responsibilities that help me stay grounded. I volunteer a few hours a week at a local food pantry, which has been a way for me to give back to the community and stay connected to the people around me. It's not much, but it reminds me of the values I was raised with—helping others, even when things are tough for you. I also try to keep up with some of my old interests, like writing. I haven't published anything in a while, but I still keep a journal and write short pieces about politics or my thoughts on the neighborhood. It's a way for me to process everything that's going on and to remember who I am beyond just being a father or a worker. I think those little things—volunteering, writing, even just taking time to reflect—help me stay balanced, even when life feels like it's moving too fast or not going the way I wanted.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Ryan Henderson: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been taking up evening walks with Emily after she goes to bed. It started as a way to clear my head and get some exercise, but it's become something more. I've started noticing the little things in the neighborhood that I used to overlook—like the way the streetlights flicker on at dusk, or how the local baker always leaves a few pastries out for the homeless folks who pass by. It's a small way to reconnect with the place I grew up in, and it's reminded me that even in the midst of uncertainty, there's beauty in the everyday. I think I'm starting to find my rhythm here, even if it's not the one I expected.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Ryan Henderson: A typical weekday for Emily starts early—usually around 7 a.m., when she gets up, brushes her teeth, and gets dressed. I help her with her breakfast, and then we head out to the bus stop together. She goes to a public school in the neighborhood, and it's a pretty good school, though it's always been a bit underfunded. She has a lot of friends there, and I think that's one of the best things about living in South Philly—she's surrounded by kids who are just like her, with all their quirks and dreams. After school, she usually has some kind of activity—sometimes it's soccer practice, other times it's art class or a science club. I try to be there for as many of those as I can, even if it means working late or adjusting my schedule. When she gets home, we have dinner, and then it's homework time. She's pretty independent now, but I still sit with her and help when she needs it. I think one of the things I value most about her routine is that it's consistent, and it gives her a sense of structure. Even though life hasn't gone the way I expected, I feel like I'm giving her a stable foundation, and that's something I can be proud of.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my wife, Sarah, and our daughter, Emily, reminded me how much my life has changed since moving back to Philadelphia. I used to think about my career more than anything, but now I realize that being a father and husband is what truly matters. When I described South Philly, I felt a mix of pride and frustration—pride in the community spirit and the history, but frustration with the challenges of finding stable work and the rising cost of living. It was also interesting to reflect on how I feel about safety here. I know it's not perfect, but I've learned to trust the people around me, and that gives me a sense of security that I didn't always have before. Overall, these questions made me think about how far I've come and how much I've grown, even if I'm not exactly where I thought I'd be.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Ryan Henderson: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been managing, but it's not always easy. I used to be pretty active in college, running a few miles most days and keeping up with a pretty healthy lifestyle. But since moving back to Philly and taking on these part-time jobs, I've been less consistent with exercise. I still try to go for walks with Emily in the evenings, and that's helped me stay somewhat in shape, but I've noticed I don't have the same stamina I used to. I also struggle with stress—between the job search, trying to provide for my family, and the uncertainty of where things are headed, it's hard not to feel the weight of it. I've been dealing with some mild anxiety, and I know I should probably see a doctor or a therapist about it, but I haven't made the time yet. I take some over-the-counter meds for occasional headaches, and I try to eat reasonably well, but I know I could be doing better. I think my health is something I've been neglecting, and I wish I had been more proactive about it. Still, I'm trying to make changes, even if they're small—like getting more sleep, eating more fruits and vegetables, and reminding myself that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Ryan Henderson: Staying healthy is easier when I have structure, like those evening walks with Emily or the routine of getting up early to get her ready for school. Those moments give me a sense of purpose and keep me moving, even if it's just a short walk or a quick breakfast. But it's hard when things get overwhelming—when I'm juggling multiple jobs, trying to keep up with Emily's needs, and worrying about the future. I know I should be taking better care of myself, but sometimes it feels like there's no time, no energy, or no place to start. I guess the biggest challenge is remembering that my health isn't just about physical fitness—it's also about mental well-being, and I haven't been as intentional about that as I should be. I want to do better, though. I think if I can find even a little more balance, it could make a big difference for me and for Emily.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Ryan Henderson: In the past two years, there wasn't a single major health event that changed everything, but there were a few things that added up. I had a pretty bad case of shingles last year, which was the first time I really felt like my body was turning against me. It was painful, and it took a few weeks to heal, but it was a wake-up call. I hadn't been sleeping well, and I was under a lot of stress, so maybe that contributed to it. I also started having some back pain, probably from sitting too much at the part-time jobs I do. It's not debilitating, but it's there, and I've had to be more careful about how I move and sit. I've been meaning to see a doctor about it, but between work and family, it's easy to push it aside. I guess what I'm trying to say is that my health hasn't been perfect, but I'm trying to be more aware of it now. I think that shingles was a sign that I needed to take better care of myself, and I'm hoping that I can make some real changes in the coming months.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Ryan Henderson: Honestly, there have been days when my health issues have made it harder to keep up with everything—especially with the part-time jobs and being there for Emily. The back pain, for instance, has made some days more difficult, and I've had to take it easy or adjust my schedule when it flares up. But I don't want to make excuses. I know I have a responsibility to my family, and I try to push through even when it's tough. The shingles scare was a reminder that I can't ignore my body's signals forever. I'm starting to realize that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy—it's about being there for the people I love. If I'm not well, I can't be the best father or husband I can be. So I'm trying to make small changes, like seeing a doctor about my back and making sure I get enough rest. It's not easy, but I know it's something I need to do—for me, and for Emily.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Ryan Henderson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just treading water. There's been a lot of uncertainty, especially with the job market here in Philadelphia. I've applied to so many positions, but it's been tough to find something that's stable or even remotely related to my degree. I keep telling myself that I'll get there eventually, but there are moments when I wonder if I'm just stuck in this cycle of part-time work and temporary gigs. At the same time, I feel a deep sense of gratitude for the little things—like seeing Emily grow, watching her learn new things, and knowing that I'm doing my best to be there for her. I think that's what keeps me going. Even when life feels overwhelming, I remind myself that I have a family to take care of, and that gives me a reason to keep pushing forward. I'm not where I wanted to be, but I'm still here, and I'm still trying.

Going through the interview questions about my recent routines, health, and the changes in my daily life made me reflect on how much I've had to adapt over the past few years. Talking about my part-time jobs, my responsibilities as a father, and the challenges of staying healthy reminded me of how far I've come from the person I was after college. I used to think my future was about career and ambition, but now I see that life is more about showing up for the people you love, even when things aren't going as planned. The questions about my health also made me confront some truths I've been avoiding—like the fact that I haven't been taking care of myself the way I should. It's not just about physical health, though; it's also about mental well-being, and I know I need to be more intentional about that. Still, I'm trying. I'm trying to find balance, to be present for Emily, and to build a life that feels meaningful, even if it's not the one I imagined. These conversations made me realize that I'm not just surviving—I'm learning, growing, and slowly finding my way forward.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Ryan Henderson: I think I've been dealing with anxiety more than I care to admit, though I haven't always recognized it for what it is. There are days when I feel like I'm constantly on edge, worrying about whether I'm doing enough for Emily, whether I'll ever find a stable job, or whether I'm failing at being the kind of father and husband I want to be. I used to think that if I just worked harder, everything would fall into place, but I've started to realize that anxiety doesn't always respond to effort—it responds to awareness and action. I've been trying to be more honest with myself about how I'm feeling, even if it's uncomfortable. I've started journaling more, and sometimes I write down my worries just to get them out of my head. I know I should probably talk to a therapist, but I've been hesitant because I don't want to feel like I'm failing or that I'm not strong enough to handle this on my own. Still, I'm starting to see that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness—it's a sign that I care enough about myself and my family to try and do better.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Ryan Henderson: For my family, it's been a mix of resilience and quiet strength. Sarah has been the rock in all of this—she's the one who keeps us grounded, who reminds me why we're doing this. She works long hours as a social worker, and I know she's seen things that would break most people, but she still shows up every day. I admire her more than I can say. Emily, she's been through a lot too, though she doesn't realize it. She's a smart kid, but she's also picked up on the stress in our home. She asks me sometimes if we're going to be okay, and I don't know how to answer that without making it sound worse than it is. I tell her we're working on it, that we're trying our best. I hope she believes that. I know I do. We're not perfect, but we're trying to build something real together, and I think that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Ryan Henderson: I think I've moved away from religion more than anything else. I was raised in an Orthodox-Christian household, and there were definitely moments when I felt the weight of those beliefs—especially growing up, when I was expected to follow certain rules and traditions. But as I got older, I started questioning a lot of those things. I don't think I'm entirely secular, though. I still believe in something bigger than myself, even if I can't put it into words the way I used to. I think it's more about the values I was taught—like kindness, compassion, and doing what's right, even when it's hard. I don't go to church anymore, and I don't really follow any specific spiritual practices, but I still find meaning in the little things: in being there for my family, in helping others when I can, and in trying to be a better person every day. I guess I've found my own kind of faith, even if it's not the one I was raised with.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Ryan Henderson: I use social media more out of habit than anything else. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with family and old friends, especially my sister Claire and her kids. I don't post much, but I like seeing what people are up to, especially when I haven't seen them in a while. I used to be more active on Twitter back when I was in college, following political debates and writing some of my own thoughts. But that faded over time, probably because I didn't have the time or energy to keep up with it. Instagram is something I barely use—maybe a few times a month to look at photos of Emily or see what friends are posting. I think social media has its place, but I've found that I prefer real, face-to-face connections. It's not that I don't like staying connected, but I've learned that sometimes the best way to do that is just by showing up, even if it's not through a screen.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Ryan Henderson: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support, even during tough times. I know people use it to vent or find encouragement, but I've always found that kind of thing harder to do online. There's something about seeing a post or a comment that feels distant, like it's not really reaching the person in the way you want it to. I've had moments where I've scrolled through old posts or messages from friends, hoping to feel connected, but it never quite replaces the real thing. I think I've always preferred talking things out face-to-face, even if it's just with Sarah or one of my friends. I know that's not always possible, especially when life gets busy, but I still believe that the kind of support that really matters comes from being there for someone in person, not just liking a post or sending a message. That said, I do appreciate the way social media keeps me in touch with people I might not otherwise hear from, and I guess I'm grateful for that, even if it's not the same as real support.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent struggles made me confront some uncomfortable truths about myself. I've been so focused on providing for my family and keeping things going that I've neglected my own well-being. The shingles last year was a wake-up call, and the back pain I've been dealing with is a reminder that I can't keep pushing through without taking care of myself. I've always thought of myself as strong, but I'm starting to realize that strength isn't just about pushing forward—it's also about knowing when to pause, when to ask for help, and when to prioritize my health. I want to be there for Emily and Sarah, but I can't do that if I'm not taking care of myself. These questions made me realize that I need to make changes, even small ones, to find a better balance between my responsibilities and my health. It's not easy, but I'm ready to try.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Ryan Henderson: In the past year, my stress and worry have definitely fluctuated. Some days, I feel like I'm managing, like I'm finding a rhythm in this new normal, and other days, it feels like I'm drowning in uncertainty. The job search has been frustrating, and I've had to accept that I might not be in the field I originally wanted to be in. That realization alone has been a source of stress, but I've been trying to reframe it. I've started using some coping strategies that I didn't think I'd ever try—like meditation, even if it's just for a few minutes before bed, or taking time to write down my thoughts instead of letting them swirl around in my head. I've also found that talking to Sarah more openly about my fears has helped. She's been my anchor, and I think that's why I've been able to find some small moments of peace. I'm not saying I'm stress-free, but I'm learning that it's okay to feel overwhelmed as long as I don't let it define me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Ryan Henderson: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and Emily's school supplies. Rent is the largest chunk of our budget—our apartment in South Philly isn't cheap, especially with the way things have been rising over the years. We're lucky to have a landlord who hasn't raised the rent too much, but it's still a struggle. Groceries are another big one, especially with Emily being in school and needing healthy meals. I try to buy in bulk and stick to what's on sale, but it's hard to avoid the cost of living increases. Then there's Emily's school supplies—she's in a public school, but they still charge for things like art materials, field trips, and uniforms. I also have to factor in the cost of her after-school activities, like soccer and science club. On top of that, we have car payments and insurance, which I didn't really think about when I first moved back. I've had to take on extra shifts at the community center to cover some of these costs, and it's not ideal, but it's what we're doing. I know we're not in a great financial position, but we're managing, and that's something I'm trying to stay grateful for.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Ryan Henderson: To be honest, our monthly spending has been pretty tight, and it's not always the same from month to month. Last month, we spent roughly around $3,200, give or take a few hundred. That's mostly on rent, which is about $1,400, groceries around $800, and then school-related expenses for Emily—art supplies, field trips, and uniforms added up to about $300. We also had to pay for her after-school activities, which cost around $200. On top of that, our car payment and insurance are about $400, and I've been spending a little extra on part-time jobs to cover unexpected costs. Usually, our spending is similar, but sometimes we have to dip into savings or adjust our budget if one of us has to work extra hours. It's not ideal, but we've learned to be flexible. I know we're not in a great financial position, but we're doing our best to make it work, and that's something I try to remind myself of every day.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Ryan Henderson: We rent our home. It's a small apartment in South Philly, and while it's not the most luxurious place, it's manageable. Rent is one of our biggest expenses, as I mentioned, and it's something we've had to be really careful with. We've considered looking into buying a house, but with the current market and our financial situation, it doesn't seem realistic right now. I think renting gives us more flexibility, especially with the way things are changing in the neighborhood. We've been here for about two years, and while I know we're not exactly where I thought I'd be at this point in my life, I feel like this place has become a real home for us. It's where Emily grows up, where Sarah and I build our life together, and where I try to make the best of every day. I don't know what the future holds, but for now, this apartment is our foundation.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Ryan Henderson: Over the past year, our bills have definitely had their ups and downs. For example, during the winter months, heating costs went up quite a bit, and we had to adjust our budget to cover that. I remember one month when the heating bill was almost $200 more than usual, and that forced us to cut back on some of our grocery spending. Then there were the holidays—Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's—when we had to spend a little more on gifts for Emily and for Sarah's family. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like a new tire for the car and some emergency repairs on the apartment's plumbing. On the flip side, there were months when things were a little easier, like in the spring when the heating costs dropped and we didn't have as many holiday-related expenses. Still, it's been a constant balancing act, trying to stay on top of everything without letting one thing spiral out of control. I think the biggest thing is that we've learned to be more flexible with our budget, and that's something I'm grateful for, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family has been through and how I've relied on them to keep going. It's easy to focus on the struggles—my job search, my health, the financial pressures—but when I think about Sarah and Emily, I realize that they've been my strength. Sarah, in particular, has been the one holding everything together, and I'm in awe of how she keeps showing up every day, even when things are hard. As for me, I've been trying to be a better father and husband, even if I don't always feel like I'm doing enough. The questions about social media reminded me that while I don't use it much for emotional support, I do appreciate the way it keeps me connected to people, even if it's not the same as being there in person. I think I'm starting to understand that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from my family, a friend, or even a professional. I've been neglecting my mental health for too long, and I know I need to do better—not just for myself, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Ryan Henderson: I've been trying to save, but it's been really hard with the way things have been. We have a small emergency fund, maybe around $1,000, but that's about it. I know it's not much, but it's something. I used to think saving was about having a big nest egg or being able to retire comfortably, but now I see it as more about having a little cushion to fall back on when things go wrong. I've started setting aside whatever I can from my part-time jobs—sometimes it's just $20 or $30 a week, but I try to be consistent. I also use a budgeting app to track our expenses, which has helped me see where we can cut back. It's not perfect, and I know I could be doing more, but I'm trying to be more mindful of our finances. I want Emily to grow up knowing that saving is important, even if we're not in the best position right now. I think that's one of the things I want to teach her—how to be responsible with money, even when life doesn't go as planned.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Ryan Henderson: For me, saving has mostly been about the rainy day kind of thing, especially over the last year. I know we're not in a position to save for a home or anything like that, but I've been trying to build that emergency fund, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control when everything else feels so uncertain. I also try to save for small things—like Emily's school supplies or a new pair of shoes—so that we don't have to worry about unexpected costs. It's not always easy, especially when we're stretching every dollar, but I think it's important to teach her the value of saving, even in small ways. I want her to know that you don't have to have a lot to be responsible with what you have. That's something I didn't really understand when I was younger, but now I see it as one of the most important lessons I can give her.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Ryan Henderson: My occupation these days is pretty much a collection of part-time jobs, but if I had to define it in one role, I'd say I'm a community worker. I do data entry for a small business in the mornings, which keeps my mind sharp and gives me a sense of structure. In the afternoons, I help out at a community center—organizing events, filing, and assisting with outreach programs. It's not the kind of work I ever imagined myself doing after college, especially with my degree in Political Science, but it's work that matters. I get to interact with people from all walks of life, and I find that really rewarding. The most important part of my job, I think, is being there for others—whether it's helping someone fill out a form, organizing a food drive, or just listening when someone needs to talk. It's not glamorous, but it's meaningful. I know I'm not where I thought I'd be at this point in my life, but I'm trying to find purpose in the work I do, even if it's not exactly what I planned.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Ryan Henderson: I usually work around 30 to 35 hours a week, depending on the week. Some weeks are busier than others, especially if the community center is hosting an event or if I need to cover an extra shift to make ends meet. I try to keep it consistent, though—mornings with data entry, afternoons at the community center, and sometimes an extra hour or two in the evenings if needed. It's not the kind of schedule I ever imagined for myself, but it's the one that keeps us going. I know I'm not working full-time, and I know I'm not in the field I studied for, but I try to remind myself that this is still work that matters. It gives me structure, it keeps me connected to the people around me, and it helps me be there for Emily. I don't know what the future holds, but for now, this schedule is what works for us.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Ryan Henderson: Yes, I've had more than one job, and honestly, it's become a way of life for me. I work data entry in the mornings, which is pretty straightforward—just entering information for a small business that handles local contracts and invoices. It's not exciting, but it pays the bills and gives me a sense of routine. Then, in the afternoons, I help out at a community center, which is where I do the most varied work. I assist with administrative tasks, organize events, help with outreach programs, and sometimes even help out with food drives or volunteer coordination. It's not always the same day to day, but that's what keeps it interesting. On top of that, I've taken on some evening shifts at the community center when they need extra help, especially during big events or when things get busy. I also do some freelance work online—mostly editing or proofreading—when I have the time. It's not a lot, but it adds up. I think having multiple jobs has become a necessity for me, not just to make ends meet, but also to keep myself busy and give me a sense of purpose. It's not ideal, but it's what I've had to do to support my family and stay on my feet.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress and emotional state have shifted over the past year, and how my family has been my anchor through it all. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me that I've been holding on to a lot of worry, especially around my job search and financial situation. I used to think I could push through everything on my own, but I've started to realize that it's okay to take small steps toward better mental health—like meditating, journaling, or just being honest with Sarah about how I'm feeling. The questions about our monthly budget and expenses also brought up a lot of feelings about how tight things have been, but I found comfort in knowing that we're managing, even if it's not the way I imagined. I've learned that being present for Emily and Sarah is what truly matters, and even though I'm not where I thought I'd be, I'm trying to find peace in the life we've built together.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Ryan Henderson: In total, our household made around $2,800 in the past month. That's from my part-time jobs, the freelance work I do online, and the occasional overtime at the community center. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics—rent, groceries, and Emily's school-related expenses. I know it's not where I thought I'd be at this point in my life, but I'm trying to make the best of it. I've learned that stability isn't always about having a high-paying job or a perfect career path—it's about showing up for the people you love, even when things are tight. I'm not where I wanted to be, but I'm still here, and I'm still trying to build something better for Emily and Sarah.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Ryan Henderson: I haven't been at any one job for very long, which is probably why I've ended up with multiple part-time positions. The data entry job I do in the mornings is with a small local business, and they don't offer any benefits—no health insurance, no paid time off, just a steady hourly wage. The community center is a bit different. They do offer some basic benefits, like a small stipend for holidays and a few days of unpaid leave if needed, but nothing close to what you'd find in a full-time position. I've been working there for about a year now, and while the work is meaningful, the lack of stability is frustrating. I used to think that having a degree in Political Science would lead to something more secure, but I've learned that in today's economy, stability is something you have to build for yourself. I'm grateful for the work I have, even if it's not perfect, and I'm trying to make the best of it while I keep looking for something more long-term.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Ryan Henderson: My relationships at work are pretty varied, honestly. At the data entry job, I don't really have much of a relationship with my manager—she's more hands-off, which is fine, but it also means there's not much in the way of feedback or support. I just show up, do the work, and leave. It's functional, but not very personal. At the community center, though, the relationships are different. I've built up a good rapport with the staff there—some of them have been around for years, and they've been really supportive. My supervisor, Maria, is someone I really respect. She's been through a lot in her own life, and she's always willing to listen or offer advice when I need it. The coworkers I work with are all pretty friendly, and we've developed a kind of camaraderie over the past year. We're not just coworkers—we're people who understand what it's like to be trying to make ends meet, to be juggling multiple responsibilities, and to still show up every day. That kind of connection makes the work feel less like a burden and more like something I can be part of, even if it's not the career I originally imagined.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Ryan Henderson: My work schedule is pretty flexible, but it's also pretty unpredictable at times. The data entry job is the most consistent—same hours every morning, which is a relief because it gives me something to count on. But the community center is more variable. Some days I might be there from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., and other days I might stay late if there's an event or if they need extra help. I appreciate the flexibility because it allows me to adjust based on Emily's schedule or if I need to take care of something else. But it also means I can't always plan too far ahead. I've learned to be adaptable, which is something I think I needed to learn after moving back to Philly and trying to rebuild my life. It's not ideal, but I've come to see it as part of the process—being able to shift and adjust as needed, even if it means working odd hours or juggling multiple things at once.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Ryan Henderson: Overall, I feel like I'm in a holding pattern, trying to stay afloat while waiting for something better to come along. It's not that I'm unhappy—far from it. I have a family I love, a daughter who makes me laugh every day, and a wife who never stops supporting me, even when I don't always deserve it. But there's a part of me that feels like I'm missing out on something, like I'm not living up to the person I thought I'd be by now. I used to think that having a stable job, a good career, and financial security were the markers of success. Now I realize that success is more about showing up for the people you love, even when life doesn't go the way you planned. I'm not where I wanted to be, but I'm not where I used to be either. I've grown in ways I didn't expect, and I think that matters more than anything. I'm not going to lie—I worry about the future, about whether I'll ever find something more fulfilling, but I also know that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. And for now, that's enough.

Going through the interview questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule brought up a lot of mixed emotions. It reminded me how much I've had to adapt financially over the past year, especially with the fluctuating costs of living and the need to manage multiple part-time jobs. I used to think of financial stability as something that came with a clear career path, but now I see it as something I have to build piece by piece, even if it means working odd hours or stretching every dollar. The questions about my savings also made me reflect on how little I've been able to set aside, but I'm trying to be more mindful of our budget and teach Emily the value of saving, no matter how small the amounts are. It's not easy, but I'm learning that financial security isn't just about having a lot—it's about being responsible with what you have and knowing that even small steps can add up over time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Ryan Henderson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a teacher, and he worked at least a year, if not more, throughout my entire childhood. He had a steady job, which gave our family a sense of stability, even though we weren't wealthy. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nurse, but she took a break from her career for a while to raise my sister and me. She went back to work part-time when I was in high school, but she always said she wanted to be there for us as much as she could. I think that's why I felt a bit torn between the values I was raised with and the more liberal views I developed later on—because I saw both sides of it. My father was always about structure, responsibility, and the importance of education, while my mother was more about compassion, family, and making sure we had what we needed. I think those two influences shaped me in a lot of ways, even if I didn't always realize it at the time.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Ryan Henderson: My father was a teacher, and his most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and, most importantly, connecting with his students. He had a way of making you feel seen, even if you were just passing through his class. He believed in education as a way to change lives, and I think that's why he stayed in the profession for so long. My mother was a nurse, and her duties involved caring for patients, administering medication, and providing comfort during some of the hardest moments in people's lives. She was incredibly dedicated, but she also had a deep sense of empathy that made her job more than just a profession—it was a calling. I remember watching her come home exhausted but still trying to be present for my sister and me. I think that's why I grew up with such a strong sense of responsibility, but also with the understanding that compassion and care are just as important as structure and discipline. Those two sides of my upbringing have always been a part of me, even if I didn't always know how to balance them.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Ryan Henderson: My father worked at a public high school in the city, and it was a place where he really made a difference. He taught history, and I remember how passionate he was about it. He didn't just read from a textbook—he brought the past to life, made you feel like you were there, like you could see the battles, hear the voices of the people who shaped the world. He worked for the school district, which meant he had a steady salary, benefits, and a pension. It wasn't a lot, but it was enough to support our family, and it gave him a sense of purpose. My mother worked at a local hospital, in the emergency room. It was a high-pressure job, but she loved it because she felt like she was making an impact every single day. She didn't make a lot of money, especially when she was working part-time, but she always said that the most important thing was being there for her patients and for us. I think that's why I grew up with such a strong sense of responsibility—because I saw what it meant to work hard, to care for others, and to do what you can with what you have.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Ryan Henderson: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here, still trying, and still finding ways to be present for Emily and Sarah. I don't know if I'll ever find that stable job I thought I'd have by now, but I hope I'll have found a way to make peace with the life I have. I hope Emily grows up knowing that her father wasn't perfect, but he loved her fiercely and did his best to give her a good life. I hope she learns that success isn't just about having a high-paying job or a prestigious title—it's about showing up for the people you love, about being kind, about being resilient. I hope I'm still volunteering at the food pantry, still writing in my journal, still taking those evening walks with Emily and noticing the little things in our neighborhood. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding meaning in the work I do, even if it's not the work I imagined. And I hope that whatever comes next, I'm ready for it—not because I have all the answers, but because I've learned that life is about showing up, day after day, and doing the best I can with what I have.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Ryan Henderson: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who keep me grounded when everything else feels uncertain. Sarah, Emily, my parents, my sister, and even the friends I've had over the years—they're the ones who remind me why I keep going. I used to think my worth was tied to my career, to my ambitions, to how much I could achieve. But now I see that the real value in life is in the relationships we build, the moments we share, and the love we give and receive. I value the small things too—the way Emily laughs when she's excited about something, the way Sarah still believes in me even when I don't believe in myself, the way the neighborhood feels like home even when it's not perfect. I value resilience, kindness, and the quiet strength it takes to keep showing up every day, even when life doesn't go the way you expect. I think that's what I want to pass on to Emily—to teach her that life isn't about having everything, but about finding meaning in what you have and being there for the people who matter most.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work life has shaped my sense of purpose and stability. Talking about my income, the multiple part-time jobs I've taken on, and the lack of benefits brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really processed before. I used to think of work as something that should define me—something that should be fulfilling, secure, and aligned with my education. But now I see that work is more about survival, about showing up every day and doing what I can to support my family. The questions about my relationships at work reminded me of how important it is to connect with people, even in small ways. I've built some meaningful connections at the community center, and that has made the work feel less like a burden and more like something I can be part of. I also realized how much I've had to adapt—how I've had to accept that my career path isn't what I expected, but that doesn't mean it's not valuable. I'm not where I thought I'd be, but I'm still trying, and I'm still learning what it means to find meaning in the work I do, even if it's not the work I imagined.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like peeling back the layers of who I am, revealing the struggles, sacrifices, and small victories that have shaped me. I never imagined my life would take this path—moving to Chicago, making the choice for love, facing the economic downturn, and eventually finding myself back in Philadelphia, working part-time jobs and raising a daughter. But as I reflected on each question, I saw how every decision, every challenge, and every moment of doubt has led me to where I am today. I've learned that life isn't about following a perfect plan or achieving the career I once dreamed of. It's about showing up for the people you love, even when things are uncertain. I've learned the value of family, the importance of resilience, and the strength it takes to keep going when the world feels heavy. I may not be where I thought I'd be, but I'm not where I used to be either. I've grown, I've changed, and I'm still learning what it means to find meaning in the life I have. This interview has reminded me that I'm not just surviving—I'm living, and that matters more than anything.
